di-ammonium.intro: Di-ammonium phosphate (DAP) is the world's most widely used phosphorus fertiliser, containing 18% nitrogen and 46% phosphorus pentoxide. Produced by reacting phosphoric acid with ammonia in a granulation plant. The phosphoric acid comes from dissolving phosphate rock in sulphuric acid. Major producers include Morocco (OCP Group), China, Saudi Arabia, and the United States. DAP granules are dark brown to black, hard, and free-flowing.
di-ammonium.materials: Dark brown-black granules with slight gloss, white phosphate rock with fossil inclusions, yellow sulphuric acid, ammonia vapour, steel granulation drum interior, rubber conveyor belt, white woven polypropylene bulk bags, fine fertiliser dust.

urea.intro: Urea (CO(NH₂)₂) is the world's most produced and traded nitrogen fertiliser, containing 46% nitrogen — the highest of any solid fertiliser. Manufactured by reacting ammonia with carbon dioxide at high pressure and temperature. The ammonia typically comes from natural gas via the Haber-Bosch process. White crystalline prills or granules that dissolve readily in water. China, India, Russia, and the Middle East are major producers.
urea.materials: White crystalline prills or granules, clear ammonia-smelling solution, steel high-pressure reactor vessels, stainless steel prilling tower walls, white dust coating surfaces, woven polypropylene bags, blue or white bulk storage dome interior.

barley.intro: Barley is a cereal grain with distinctive long awns (whiskers) extending from each kernel. Two-row barley is preferred for malting (beer and whisky production), while six-row and feed barley are used for animal feed. The grain has a tightly adhering husk that remains after threshing. Barley is tolerant of poor soils and short growing seasons, making it one of the most widely adapted cereals, grown from Scandinavia to Ethiopia.

corn.intro: Corn (maize) is the world's most produced cereal grain, used for animal feed, ethanol production, corn syrup, starch, and direct human consumption. The ear develops wrapped in husks on a stalk 2-3 metres tall, with golden kernels packed in tight rows around a central cob. The US Corn Belt (Iowa, Illinois, Indiana, Nebraska) produces roughly 30% of global supply. CBOT corn futures are the benchmark contract.
corn.materials: Golden-yellow dried kernels packed on a white cob, green husk leaves wrapped around the ear, pale silk threads emerging from the husk top, rough dried stalk after harvest, fine pale yellow cornmeal, white starchy flour, green young crop in spring.

oat.intro: Oats are a cereal grain uniquely suited to cool, wet climates where wheat and barley struggle. The grain hangs in an open panicle (branching seed head) rather than a tight ear, giving oat fields a distinctive airy, shimmering appearance in the wind. Oats have a higher fat content than other cereals, giving porridge its creamy texture. Used for human food (porridge, oatmeal, granola), animal feed, and increasingly in plant-based milk.
oat.materials: Pale cream-coloured groats inside a papery brown husk, open branching panicle seed head, rolled flat oat flakes, fine oatmeal flour, creamy porridge texture, steel-cut angular chunks, pale golden straw.

rice.intro: Rice is the staple food for over half the world's population, a semi-aquatic grass cultivated in flooded paddies (wetland rice) or rain-fed upland fields. The grain grows in a panicle at the top of a metre-tall stem, ripening from green to golden-brown. After harvesting, the husk is removed to produce brown rice; further milling removes the bran layer to produce white rice. Indica varieties (long-grain, separate when cooked) dominate tropical production; japonica (short-grain, sticky) is grown in temperate East Asia.

wheat.intro: Wheat is a cereal grass cultivated across every continent except Antarctica. Winter wheat is sown in autumn and harvested mid-summer; spring wheat completes its cycle in one growing season. The grain head (ear) contains 20-50 individual kernels arranged in tight rows along a central stem (rachis). Wheat is the world's most widely grown crop by area and the basis for bread, pasta, pastry, and noodles globally.

canola.intro: Canola (Canadian Oil Low Acid) is a cultivar of rapeseed bred for low erucic acid and glucosinolate content, making it safe for human consumption and animal feed. The plant produces brilliant yellow flowers that develop into long thin seed pods (siliques) containing small round black or brown seeds with 40-45% oil content. Canada is the world's largest exporter. Canola oil is the third most consumed vegetable oil globally, prized for its neutral flavour and healthy fatty acid profile.
canola.materials: Brilliant yellow four-petalled flowers in dense clusters, thin green seed pods splitting when dry, small round dark brown-black seeds, pale golden pressed oil, grey-brown seed meal cake after pressing, green branching stems.

palm_oil.intro: Palm oil is extracted from the flesh of the fruit of the oil palm (Elaeis guineensis), a tropical tree that produces dense bunches of reddish-orange fruit year-round. The world's most produced and consumed vegetable oil — used in cooking, food manufacturing, cosmetics, and biodiesel. Indonesia and Malaysia produce over 85% of global supply. The fresh fruit bunches (FFB) must be processed within 24 hours of harvest to prevent free fatty acid buildup. Crude palm oil (CPO) is deep orange-red due to high beta-carotene content.
palm_oil.materials: Dense bunch of reddish-orange oval fruits, dark fibrous mesocarp around each fruit, hard black palm kernel inside, deep orange-red crude palm oil, pale refined oil after bleaching, spiky frond stems, grey palm trunk with ring scars.

rapeseed.intro: Rapeseed (Brassica napus) is the parent species from which canola was bred. European rapeseed varieties may contain higher erucic acid levels used for industrial lubricants, biodiesel, and animal feed. The crop is visually identical to canola — brilliant yellow flowers in spring, developing into thin seed pods. The EU is the world's largest rapeseed producer, with Germany, France, and Poland leading. Rapeseed oil is the primary feedstock for European biodiesel (FAME).
rapeseed.materials: Brilliant yellow four-petalled flowers identical to canola, thin green seed pods, small round dark seeds, golden pressed oil, grey seed meal, green branching stems, biodiesel with slight yellow tint.

soybeans.intro: Soybeans are the world's most important oilseed crop, containing approximately 18-20% oil and 35-40% protein — an unusually high protein content for a plant. The bushy plant grows knee to waist height, with small pods containing 2-4 round yellow beans. Used for soybean oil (cooking, industrial), soybean meal (the dominant protein in animal feed globally), tofu, soy sauce, soy milk, and biodiesel. The US and Brazil are the world's two largest producers, together accounting for roughly 60% of global output.
soybeans.materials: Round yellow-beige beans with visible hilum scar, hairy brown pods in clusters of 2-4, green trifoliate leaves, pale yellow crude soybean oil, tan-coloured soy meal flakes, white tofu blocks, dark soy sauce.

sunflower_oil.intro: Sunflower oil is pressed from the seeds of the common sunflower (Helianthus annuus), a tall annual plant growing 1.5-3 metres with a large flower head 15-30cm across containing up to 2,000 seeds. Ukraine and Russia together produce over 50% of global sunflower oil, making it geopolitically significant. The oil has a light, clean flavour and high smoke point, making it popular for frying. High-oleic varieties are increasingly grown for healthier fat profiles.
sunflower_oil.materials: Large yellow-petalled flower head with dark seed disc centre, black-and-white striped seeds tightly packed in spiral pattern, pale golden pressed oil, grey-brown seed meal, tall rough green stems, broad heart-shaped leaves.

beef.intro: Beef cattle are raised on pasture (grass-fed) or finished in feedlots (grain-fed) depending on the production system. The global industry ranges from Argentine gauchos and Australian station hands managing vast pastoral properties to intensive US feedlot operations with 100,000+ head. Major breeds include Angus (black, marbled), Hereford (red-and-white face), Brahman (tropical, humped), and Wagyu (extreme marbling). The US, Brazil, and Australia are the world's three largest exporters.
beef.materials: Deep red marbled meat with white fat ribbons, thick hide with hair, horn and bone, worn leather saddle and rope, steel cattle yard rails, wooden fence posts, grass underfoot, dust in cattle yards.

butter.intro: Butter is made by churning cream until the fat globules aggregate into a solid mass, separating from the liquid buttermilk. European-style butter contains at least 82% butterfat (vs 80% in the US), giving it a richer flavour and better baking performance. Colour ranges from pale cream (grain-fed cows) to deep yellow (grass-fed, high beta-carotene). Major exporting regions include the EU (Ireland, Netherlands, Denmark), New Zealand, and the US. Butter is a key price indicator for the global dairy market.
butter.materials: Pale cream to deep yellow solid fat, smooth cut surface with slight sheen, parchment or foil wrapper, wooden butter paddle marks, cream-coloured buttermilk liquid, stainless steel churn interior, refrigerated display case.

cheese.intro: Cheese is produced by coagulating milk protein (casein) with rennet or acid, draining the whey, then pressing, salting, and ageing the resulting curd. There are over 1,800 named varieties globally. Hard aged cheeses (Cheddar, Parmesan, Gruyère) lose moisture during maturation and develop complex flavours. Soft cheeses (Brie, Camembert) develop surface moulds. Global cheese production exceeds 22 million tonnes annually, with the EU and US as the largest producers.
cheese.materials: Pale yellow to deep orange cheese paste, white or grey natural rind, wax coating in various colours, blue-green mould veins, circular or cylindrical wheels, muslin or bandage cloth wrapping, wooden shelving in ageing caves, stainless steel vat walls, white curd particles.

cocoa.intro: Cocoa comes from the cacao tree (Theobroma cacao), a tropical understorey tree that produces large colourful pods directly from the trunk and major branches (cauliflory). Each pod contains 30-50 almond-shaped beans embedded in sweet white mucilage. After harvesting, beans are fermented for 5-7 days (developing chocolate flavour precursors), then sun-dried. West Africa (Côte d'Ivoire, Ghana) produces roughly 60% of global supply. Cocoa is traded as raw beans, cocoa butter, cocoa powder, and cocoa liquor.

coffee.intro: Coffee is a tropical evergreen shrub grown between the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn at 600-2000m altitude. Arabica dominates speciality markets; Robusta is hardier and higher-yielding. The fruit (cherry) ripens from green to deep red over 6-8 months. Each cherry contains two seeds — the coffee beans.

cotton.intro: Cotton is a soft white fibre that grows in a boll (protective case) around the seeds of the cotton plant. When the boll matures and splits open, the fluffy white lint is exposed for harvesting. Each fibre is a single elongated cell, 2-3cm long, that can be spun into thread. Upland cotton (Gossypium hirsutum) accounts for 90% of production. The US, India, China, Brazil, and Pakistan are the largest producers. Cotton is traded by staple length, strength, and colour grade — longer staple commands premium prices.

eggs_ch.intro: China produces roughly 40% of the world's eggs — over 30 million tonnes annually — more than any other country by a wide margin. Production ranges from massive modern cage and aviary operations to small rural backyard flocks. Chinese egg pricing is benchmarked in yuan per jin (500g). Layer hens are predominantly Hy-Line Brown or local breeds like the Jingfen. Eggs are a staple protein source in Chinese cuisine, consumed boiled, fried, steamed, in soups, and as preserved eggs (century eggs and salted eggs).

eggs_us.intro: The United States produces roughly 8 billion dozen eggs annually, the world's second-largest output after China. Production is dominated by large-scale cage, cage-free, and free-range operations concentrated in Iowa, Ohio, Indiana, and Pennsylvania. US eggs are priced per dozen at the CME and graded by USDA size (Jumbo, Extra Large, Large, Medium) and quality (AA, A, B). White-shelled eggs from White Leghorn hens dominate commercial production, though brown eggs from Rhode Island Reds and other breeds command a premium.
eggs_us.materials: White-shelled eggs with smooth matte surface, brown eggs with slightly rougher texture, yellow straw in nest boxes, wire cage mesh, cardboard dozen-carton with flip lid, styrofoam or moulded-fibre tray, bright orange-yellow yolk, white feathers.

feeder_cattle.intro: Feeder cattle are young beef animals (typically 6-10 months old, weighing 300-450kg) that have been weaned and are ready to enter a feedlot for grain finishing. The CME Feeder Cattle contract is a key livestock futures benchmark. These animals bridge the gap between cow-calf ranching (origin) and fed-cattle slaughter (endpoint). Most feeder cattle in the US originate from cow-calf operations in the Southeast, Ozarks, Great Plains, and Mountain West, then move to Corn Belt or Southern Plains feedlots.
feeder_cattle.materials: Young muscular cattle with growing frames, mixed black and red hides, ear tags and sometimes brands, steel cattle chute and headgate, wooden auction ring rails, dusty pen ground, hay and mineral feeders, livestock trailer steel sides.

kraft_pulp.intro: Kraft pulp is the dominant form of chemical wood pulp, produced by cooking wood chips in a solution of sodium hydroxide and sodium sulphide (white liquor) at high temperature and pressure. This dissolves the lignin binding the wood fibres together, producing strong unbleached brown pulp or bright white bleached pulp. 'Kraft' means 'strength' in German and Swedish. Used for packaging, printing paper, tissue, and speciality papers. Major producers include Brazil (eucalyptus), Scandinavia (spruce/pine), and Canada (spruce/pine).
kraft_pulp.materials: Brown unbleached pulp sheets with visible wood fibre texture, white bleached pulp bales, green wood chips, dark brown cooking liquor, tall digester vessel, white chemical recovery boiler stack, eucalyptus or spruce logs with bark.

lean_hogs.intro: Lean hogs are the CME benchmark for pork — measuring the value of the actual meat (lean) on a finished market-weight hog (approximately 120kg live weight). The US is the world's third-largest pork producer after China and the EU, with Iowa, Minnesota, North Carolina, and Illinois leading production. Modern production is highly vertically integrated, from genetics through finishing barns to packing plants. Pork is the world's most widely consumed meat.
lean_hogs.materials: Pink-skinned hogs with sparse white bristle hair, concrete and slatted flooring, steel pen dividers, automated feed and water systems, straw bedding in some systems, pink marbled pork cuts, white back-fat layer, stainless steel processing equipment.

live_cattle.intro: Live cattle futures (CME) represent finished (fat) cattle ready for slaughter, typically weighing 550-640kg after grain finishing in feedlots. These are the endpoint of the beef production chain — animals that started as calves on cow-calf ranches, passed through the feeder cattle stage, and have been grain-finished to market condition with adequate fat cover and marbling. The US, Brazil, and Australia are the world's largest fed-cattle producers.

lumber.intro: Lumber (timber in the UK) refers to wood that has been processed into standard dimensional boards and planks for construction. Softwood lumber from spruce, pine, and fir (SPF) dominates structural construction. The CME Random Length Lumber contract prices 2x4 and other framing lumber, primarily from British Columbia, the US Pacific Northwest, and the US South. Lumber prices are highly volatile, driven by housing starts, mill capacity, and beetle kill in forests.

milk.intro: Milk is the raw material for the entire dairy industry — consumed fresh (fluid milk) or processed into cheese, butter, yoghurt, ice cream, and milk powder. Global production exceeds 930 million tonnes annually, with India, the EU, and the US as the largest producers. Class III milk (used for cheese) is the CME benchmark. Milk is collected from farms by refrigerated tanker within hours of milking, maintaining the cold chain from cow to consumer.

orange_juice.intro: Frozen concentrated orange juice (FCOJ) is the benchmark contract on ICE, representing the most traded form of processed orange juice. Fresh oranges are squeezed, the juice is concentrated by evaporation to remove water, then frozen for transport and storage. Brazil (São Paulo state) produces roughly 70% of global orange juice, with Florida as the other major source — though Florida production has declined dramatically due to citrus greening disease (HLB). FCOJ is reconstituted with water before retail sale.
orange_juice.materials: Bright orange fruit with dimpled peel texture, dark green glossy citrus leaves, white fragrant blossoms, pale yellow pulpy juice, frozen concentrate cylinders, glass of bright orange liquid, citrus peel oil droplets.

potatoes.intro: Potatoes are the world's fourth-largest food crop, a starchy tuber that grows underground on the roots of a bushy green plant. Varieties range from waxy (firm when cooked, for salads) to floury (fluffy when cooked, for baking and chips). Major producers include China, India, Russia, Ukraine, and the US (Idaho and Washington lead). European potato futures trade on Eurex. The crop is propagated vegetatively from seed potatoes rather than true seeds.

poultry.intro: Poultry (broiler chicken) is the world's most efficient converter of feed to meat — reaching market weight of approximately 2.5kg in just 35-42 days. Global production exceeds 100 million tonnes annually, with the US, Brazil, China, and the EU as the largest producers. The industry is highly vertically integrated, with companies like Tyson, JBS, and BRF controlling genetics, feed, growing, and processing. Chicken is the most consumed meat globally, having overtaken pork and beef.

rubber.intro: Natural rubber is harvested as latex — a milky white fluid — from the rubber tree (Hevea brasiliensis) by cutting a thin spiral groove in the bark (tapping). The latex drips into a cup and is collected daily. Thailand, Indonesia, and Vietnam produce over 70% of global natural rubber, primarily for tyre manufacturing. The trees require tropical conditions (25-28°C, 2000mm+ rainfall) and begin producing at 5-7 years of age. Rubber is traded as ribbed smoked sheets (RSS) or technically specified rubber (TSR).

salmon.intro: Farmed Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar) is the world's most valuable single-species aquaculture product, raised in floating sea cages (net pens) in cold coastal waters. Norway is the largest producer, followed by Chile, Scotland, and Canada. The fish are hatched in freshwater hatcheries, transferred to sea cages at the smolt stage, and grown for 12-18 months to a harvest weight of 4-6kg. Salmon's distinctive pink-orange flesh colour comes from astaxanthin in the feed. Fish farming is one of the most efficient animal protein production systems.

sugar.intro: Sugar is produced from two crops: sugarcane (a tropical grass producing roughly 80% of global sugar) and sugar beet (a temperate root crop producing the remaining 20%). Raw sugar is traded as ICE No. 11 (world benchmark) and refined white sugar as No. 5 (London). Brazil is the dominant producer and exporter — the Centro-Sul region (São Paulo state) alone produces more sugar than any other country. Sugarcane is crushed to extract juice, which is clarified, evaporated, and crystallised. Sugar beet is sliced, soaked, and the sugar extracted by diffusion.

tea.intro: Tea comes from the evergreen shrub Camellia sinensis, with the top two leaves and a bud ('two leaves and a bud') hand-plucked for quality production. The same plant produces green, black, white, and oolong tea depending on processing (withering, rolling, oxidation, firing). China and India are the largest producers; Kenya is the largest exporter. Tea is the world's most consumed beverage after water. Major auction centres include Mombasa (Kenya), Colombo (Sri Lanka), and Kolkata (India).

wool.intro: Wool is the natural fibre shorn from sheep, with quality ranging from ultra-fine Merino (15-20 microns, for luxury suiting) to coarse crossbred wool (30+ microns, for carpets). Australia is the world's largest fine-wool producer, with the Australian Wool Exchange (AWEX) Eastern Market Indicator as the global benchmark price. New Zealand dominates crossbred wool. Wool is shorn annually in spring, graded by fibre diameter (micron), staple length, and vegetable matter content, then sold at auction.
